Hrvaška ne bo več določala kvot za uvoz tujih delavcev
06 Nov 2019, 11:10 by STA

Hrvaška vlada ne namerava več določati kvot za uvoz delavcev, temveč bodo potrebe za delovno silo iz drugih držav določali na podlagi podatkov zavoda za zaposlovanje, podobno kot to velja v Sloveniji. Liberalizacija trga dela je del predloga novega hrvaškega zakona o tujcih, ki je v javni razpravi.



Hrvaška vlada ne namerava več določati kvot za uvoz delavcev, temveč bodo potrebe za delovno silo iz drugih držav določali na podlagi podatkov zavoda za zaposlovanje. 

ZAGREB > Hrvaški delodajalec, ki bo želel zaposliti delavca iz tujine, bo moral pri področni službi zavoda za zaposlovanje preveriti, ali imajo v svojih evidencah brezposelne osebe, ki ustrezajo potrebam odprtega delovnega mesta. Če jih ni, bo zavod za zaposlovanje objavil mnenje, s katerim bodo na policiji lahko izdali delovno dovoljene za tuje delavce.
Načrtujejo, da omenjeni postopek ne bo veljal za zaposlitve sezonskih delavcev v kmetijstvu niti za deficitarne poklice na Hrvaškem. Obenem določajo, da delež tujih delavcev pri nekemu delodajalcu ne sme biti višji od tretjine vseh zaposlenih pri tem delodajalcu.
Delovne sile ne bodo mogli uvažati lastniki podjetij, ki so v težavah zaradi nelikvidnosti, imajo blokirane račune, ne plačujejo davkov ali nimajo zaposlenih.
Na Hrvaškem ocenjujejo, da bo za uveljavitev novega zakona potrebno prehodno obdobje. Zato je neuradno slišati, da bo hrvaška vlada vsaj za začetek prihodnjega leta znova razpisala kvote za uvoz delavcev. Iz hrvaškega združenja delodajalcev (Hup) so za leto 2020 že predlagali začasno kvoto uvoza 81.600 delavcev. Hkrati so pozdravili predlog zakona, ker menijo, da bodo v prihodnjem letu še težje zadržali hrvaške delavce, ker bo tudi Avstrija odprla svoj trg za hrvaške državljane.
V sindikatih nasprotujejo liberalizaciji hrvaškega trga dela za delavce iz drugih držav. Prepričani so, da bodo na ta način ustavili zvišanje plač na Hrvaškem, ker bodo delodajalci svojo konkurenčnost zagotavljali s poceni delovno silo namesto na vlaganjih v posodobitev proizvodnje.

Croatia will no longer set quotas on imports of foreign workers
06 Nov 2019, 11:10 by STA

The Croatian government no longer intends to set quotas for the import of workers, but will determine labor requirements from other countries based on data from the Employment Service, similar to the situation in Slovenia. Labor market liberalization is part of a proposal for a new Croatian law on aliens that is under debate.



The Croatian government no longer plans to set quotas for the import of workers, but will determine labor needs from other countries based on data from the Employment Service.

ZAGREB> A Croatian employer wishing to hire a worker from abroad will have to check with the Employment Service of the Employment Service that they have unemployed persons who meet the needs of an open job. If they are not, the Employment Service will publish an opinion allowing the police to issue work permits for foreign workers.
They plan that the procedure will not apply to the employment of seasonal workers in agriculture or to scarce occupations in Croatia. At the same time, they stipulate that the share of foreign workers with an employer must not exceed one third of all employees with that employer.
Workers will not be able to import business owners who are in trouble due to illiquidity, have blocked accounts, pay no taxes or have no employees.
In Croatia, it is estimated that a transitional period will be required for the new law to take effect. It is therefore unofficial to hear that the Croatian government will again tender quotas for the import of workers by the beginning of next year. The Croatian Employers Association (HUP) has already proposed a temporary import quota of 81,600 workers for 2020. At the same time, they welcomed the bill because they believe it will be even harder to retain Croatian workers next year, as Austria will also open up its market to Croatian citizens.
Trade unions oppose the liberalization of the Croatian labor market for workers from other countries. They are convinced that in this way they will stop the wage increase in Croatia, because employers will ensure their competitiveness by cheap labor instead of investing in modernization of production.
